attributes.title: Self-relevance supersedes reward value during facial mimicry of conditioned happy faces
Emotional identification and perception of facial disfigurement
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
1.	The type of faces: categorical variable with 2 levels (control, disfigurement), mixed within- and between-participant
2.	The AoI (area of interest): categorical variable with five levels (eyes, nose, cheek with or without burning scar, other cheek, mouth), within-participant
3.	Emotional scales: categorical variable with six levels (sorrow, fear, surprise, hate, disgust, neutral), within-participant

question2b.value:
1.	Indicators of visual attention : eye tracking technology (Tobii pro) is recording: 
•	Dwell time (total time spent fixating on a region over the course of a trial), 
•	First fixation time (how quickly a region was fixated relative to the onset of the image),
•	Total time spent visiting on a region over the course of a trial: A relative importance score of the disfigurement will be calculated by subtracting the rating of the target AoI (i.e., with the disfigurement) from each of the other areas resulting in 4 scores. 
•	Visit count : number of visits on a region over the course of a trial.

2.	Emotional state scale : 
The questionnaire contains a list of 18 emotion related words. Following a pretest, these emotions have been grouped in 6 categories. These are: sympathy (sympathy, tenderness, benevolence), fear (fear, apprehension, anxiety), surprise (astonishment, surprise, curiosity), neutral (indifference, calm, neutrality), disgust (disgust, nausea, repulsion), hate (hatred, wickedness, contempt). Participant will have to state the perceived emotional reaction of people facing the face they are watching on the screen. The scale will range from 1 (« not at all ») to 7 (« very much »).

question10b.value:
On arrival, they will be given an informed consent for their participation. All participants will be naïve to the hypotheses of the experiment. As there is no experimental condition (just a counterbalancing of the presentation of the face in its disfigured or control version), there will be no double blinding. 
First, the eye-tracker will be calibrated. Each trial will consist of the following sequence: a fixation cross in the center of the screen for 2 seconds, the face will afterwards be presented for 5 seconds, then participants will report “to which extent most people that see the person on the photograph may experience” the written emotion on a numeric scale of 1–7 (corresponding to: 1- “totally disagree”, 4 – “neither agree nor disagree”, 7 - “totally agree”). We will use a fixed random order presentation for each pair of face and emotion. For that purpose, the "alea()" function of Excel software will be used. Each trial will last approximately 10 seconds. Each face will be presented 18 times, once for each emotion, making a total of 72 trials. At the end, participants will see two photographs of celebrities smiling paired with questions about happiness to prevent from emotional decrease (that will not be recorded). All participants will then complete a socio-demographic questionnaire before being debriefed and thanked for their participation. The entire procedure will take approximately 15 minutes. 
A mixed within- and between-participant design will be employed both to prevent from creating expectations among participants and to control the emotional impact of a particular face. Two sets of faces will thus be constituted. We will use a simple randomization: equal numbers of participants will view each set of faces. To create these 2 sets the "alea()" function of Excel software will be used to generate a random number list.

question1a.value:
H1. Participants will think that people feel more negative and less positive emotions when facing a disfigurement. 

H2. More and quicker visual attention will be given to the disfigurement location when facing a face with a disfigurement.

H3. Visual attention will mediate the relationship between disfigurement and the perception of emotions.

question2a.value:
H1. Participants should state that people feel less positive emotions, more negative emotions when facing a disfigured face vs control face.

H2. Participants should attend longer on the disfigurement and shorter on the eyes, nose and mouth. Participants should be attending quicker on the disfigurement and later on the eyes, nose and mouth.

H3. The longer participants will be attending on the disfigurement and the shorter on the eyes, nose and mouth the less participants should feel positive emotions, the more they should feel negative emotions when facing a disfigured face (vs control face). Moreover, the quicker participants will be attending on the disfigurement and the later on the eyes, nose and mouth, the less participants should feel positive emotions, the more they should feel negative emotions when facing a disfigured face (vs control face).

question3a.value: We will simply ask participants if they have noticed that some faces had a disfigurement. Please note that we have already used this material and participants always noticed the disfigurement.

question5a.value:
People with facial disfigurement (FD; i.e., a state of deep and persistent harmed appearance; Krishna, 2009) report social difficulties such as negative behaviors, avoidance, unsolicited attention, and negative stereotypes (Wali & Regmi, 2016). In accordance with these perceptions, studies using eye-tracking technology revealed that observers gave more attention to a specific face location when disfigured compared to control, which in turn had downstream effects on impression formation (Madera & Hebl, 2012). 
This focus on the appearance and the focalization on the disfigured part of the face may be due to objectification (i.e., the perception and treatment of people as things; Bernard, Gervais, & Klein, 2018). One indicator of cognitive objectification is the objectifying gaze, which has been operationalized in eye-tracking studies as paying more attention to people bodies and less attention to their faces (Gervais, Holland, & Dodd, 2013). In a preliminary study, we investigated the role of attending at the internal expressive features as a new way to investigate a possible cognitive objectification that is more relevant for people with FD. We observed that participants gave more visual attention to the disfigurement location (compared to control face) and that eyes were the most internal expressive feature impaired. 
Regarding the previous work of Stone and Potton (2017), the aim of this study will be to show the emotional consequences in this shift of visual attention that we previously evidenced and to discuss it in regard to the objectification theory.

question1c.value:
For H1. 
Computed score of the following emotional dimensions:
•	Positive self-responsible emotion: a scale computed with the mean of the 3 related emotions
•	Positive other responsible emotion: a scale computed with the mean of the 3 related emotions
•	Negative self-responsible emotion: a scale computed with the mean of the 3 related emotions
•	Negative other responsible emotion: a scale computed with the mean of the 3 related emotions
•	Neutral self-responsible emotion: a scale computed with the mean of the 3 related emotions
•	Neutral other responsible emotion: a scale computed with the mean of the 3 related emotions

question2c.value: A mixed model will be used if the ICC value of the face (random component) is greater than 0.05. Otherwise, a repeated measures ANOVA will be used, then two mean scores of each emotional dimension will be computed: one for the disfigured faces, one for the non-disfigured faces.

Moderator: 
- Each eye-tracking indicator for both disfigured and non-disfigured faces and for each AoI (cf second prediction).

question1c.value:
For H2. 
Computed score of eye-tracking indicators:
•	First fixation time (how quickly a region was fixated relative to the onset of the image): it will be calculated by determining, relative to the onset of the trial, how long it took participants to initially fixate each AoI (except for nose),
•	Dwell time (total time spent fixating on a region over the course of a trial): it will be calculated by summing the total duration (in ms) participants spent fixating on each AoI over the duration of each,
•	Total time spent visiting on a region over the course of a trial: it will be calculated by summing the total duration (in ms) participants spent visiting on each AoI over the duration of each. A relative importance score of the disfigurement will be calculated by subtracting the rating of the target AoI (i.e., with the disfigurement) from each of the other areas resulting in 4 scores. 
•	Visit count (number of visits on a region over the course of a trial): a mean score will be computed for each AoI.

question2c.value: A mixed model will be used if the ICC value of the face (random component) is greater than 0.05. Otherwise, a repeated measures ANOVA will be used, then two mean scores of each eye-tracking indicator will be computed: one for the disfigured faces, one for the non-disfigured faces.

question3c.value:
IV: 
- Disfigurement
- AoI 
DV: 
- Each eye-tracking indicator mentioned above for both disfigured and non-disfigured faces and for each AoI.

attributes.title: Monocusp valves do not improve early operative mortality in Tetralogy of Fallot; a meta analysis.

summary.value:
Surgical repair of tetralogy of Fallot in pediatric patients, often involves relief of right ventricular out flow tract obstruction(RVOTO). Both significant residual RVOTO and adequate relief of RVOTO may adversely affect the long term surgical outcome. Adequate relief of RVOTO may require division of the pulmonary valve annulus; this results in pulmonary valve incompetence which is thought to compromise  right ventricular function resulting in worse early postoperative outcomes.There is evidence that the creation of a monocusp valve restores pulmonary valve competence in the early postoperative period; this may reduce operative morbidity. It is often assumed that documented reductions in morbidity also translate to reductions in early post operative mortality. A Meta-analysis of randomised clinical trials (RCTs) is considered the highest form of evidence that may be used to guide patient care. It is established practice to perform meta-analyses of observational studies where no RCTs exist. As there are no RCTs comparing outcomes, with and without a monocusp valve, we performed a meta-analysis of observational studies in accordance with established protocols. 

In accordance with PRISMA-P checklist,  PUBMED, the Cochrane Library and Google Scholar will be searched systematically until January 2020 using the search terms “tetralogy”; “pulmonary”; “transannular”;  “cusp”; “monocusp” “monocuspid”; “factors”; “outcome”; “outcomes”; “early” and “results”. Titles and abstracts will be interrogated and full-text articles will be obtained when the abstract indicates that there is a possibility that a study may include a group of pediatric patients who had a transannular patch with a monocusp and a group of pediatric patients who had a transannular patch without a monocusp. The outcome of interest will be in-hospital operative mortality. Non-English language studies and non-human studies will be  excluded. Only studies where the mean or median age of subjects is less than 18 years old will be included.

attributes.title: Switch Cost Asymmetry in the IAT
The Impact of Prematurity on Social Understanding

q1.value: The Impact of Prematurity on Social Understanding (IPSU)

q2.value: Catherine Laverty, Andrew Surtees, Caroline Richards

q3.value: Autism, a complex neurodevelopmental disorder, occurs at heightened rates in children born prematurely. Autism is defined by difficulties with social communication and repetitive and restricted behaviours. The diagnostic deficits in social communication include specific problems with understanding the perspectives of others and the complexities of the social world. Heightened rates of autism in children born preterm suggest that being born early may affect the development of social understanding; however, this has not been confirmed experimentally. Using play-based tasks and eye-tracking methods we aim to describe the profile of social abilities in a cohort of children born preterm.

q4.value:
1.	To assess the profile of ASD phenomenology in preterm infants
2.	To identify participant characteristics that may be associated with ASD phenomenology in preterm samples

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The proposed design will be a case-control study comparing the social-cognitive profile of children born mid-late preterm and full term.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: As late-preterm children will not always be followed up in neonatal services, we will utilise a number of pathways to recruit the preterm sample. We will recruit via health visitor and well child clinics across Birmingham. We will also recruit via West Midlands Bliss groups and Bliss email registries; Bliss are the UK's leading charity for babies born premature or sick. The term comparison group will be recruited through local nurseries and via health visitor and well child clinics. For both groups, we will also recruit via existing databases.

q13.value:
A minimum of 20 children and their parents/carers who meet the following criteria will be recruited to each of the following groups;
Preterm group (N=20-45):
Aged 18-36 months
Born mid-late preterm (32+0 - 36+6/7 weeks gestation)
No siblings with idiopathic autism as genetic risk for social-cognitive difficulties are heightened in the siblings of individuals with autism.

Comparison group (N=20-45);
18- 36 months old age-matched (corrected for gestational age of preterm cohort)
Born 37+0 - 41+6/7 weeks gestation
No siblings with idiopathic autism

Sample sizes may vary based upon logistical constraints of the project. Current recruitment range estimates are based upon analysis that suggested participant numbers would be sufficient to detect a moderate to large effect size.

question.value:
Short Questionnaire Pack
This will include background information regarding socio-economic status and neonatal history.

Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers – Revised; M-CHAT-R
The M-CHAT-R is a robust screening tool for autism in young children, with high sensitivity and specificity.

Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS)
The ADOS is a widely accepted “gold standard” play-based diagnostic instrument, designed to elicit social interaction and communication behaviours in children including social smiling, responding to name and joint attention. Reports of the psychometric properties of the ADOS reveal high interrater reliability, internal consistency and test-retest reliability 

The Social Orienting Continuum and Response Scale (SOC-RS)
The SOC-RS is an observational coding system of four social orienting behaviours; social referencing, orienting to name, social smiling and joint attention. The SOC-RS employs retrospective coding of social orienting behaviour applied to previously recorded ADOS assessments. This will enable us to capture dimensional ratings of social orienting behaviour using a standardised procedure, to provide richer information that the categorical ratings provided by the ADOS. 

Mullen Scales of Early Learning (MSEL)
The MSEL is an IQ assessment for children aged 0-68 months and provides standardised scores across five domains pertaining to gross motor, visual reception, fine motor, expressive language, and receptive language. The scale is widely used in experimental and developmental psychology in young children. Children in each group will be matched for developmental ability to ensure that any obtained differences in social cognition are not due to developmental ability in children born preterm.

The Early Social Cognitive Battery 
The Early Social Cognition Battery will be used as a direct assessment of early social understanding. The Early Social Cognition Battery is a scaled, play-based assessment that allows for calculation of a total score of early social understanding. The battery includes seven tasks of social cognition, drawn from the existing child development literature and progressing beyond joint attention to assess diverse social cognitive skills. An example of these tasks is the ‘Helping’ assessment where the child watches the adult draw using a pen, and then ‘accidentally’ drop the pen and unsuccessfully reach for it. The child’s response is coded to determine whether they can understand another person’s intentions and unachieved goals. As these seven tasks scale in a known developmental trajectory with published norms, we will test whether children born mid-late preterm show deficits or divergent trajectories in these early social-cognitive skills compared to the term born cohort.

Eye-Tracking
Brief eye-tracking paradigms will be used to evaluate implicit differences in social attention between the two groups. We  will compare children’s attentional preferences when viewing static and dynamic social and non-social stimuli as well as biological motion stimuli. The eye-tracking tasks will capture differences in attention via measures of dwell time and first fixation latency elucidating fundamental attentional processes that may drive deficits or differences in social understanding.

Interviews
Following their assessment day, parents may be contacted to arrange a time convenient to them in the following 6-8 weeks to complete a telephone interview. The interview consists of open ended questions assessing experiences at home. This data will be used to supplement the quantitative data. Interviews will be audio recorded and transcribed by the research team

Between group analyses will be undertaken to evaluate putative differences in early social cognition between children born preterm and children born at term. Data will be tested for normality; where data are not normally distributed, non-parametric tests will be conducted. A t-test will be used to test for differences in the Early Social Cognition Battery scores between the preterm and term samples. A series of 2 × 2 mixed ANOVAs will be conducted to test for difference in eye-tracking parameters (dwell time and first fixation latencies) where stimuli (social or non-social) or character belief (“true belief” or “false belief”) will be the within subjects factor and participant group (preterm or term) the between subjects factor. 

Further exploratory analysis will also be conducted dependant on data.

registration_responses.q2: Catherine Laverty, Andrew Surtees, Caroline Richards
registration_responses.q3: Autism, a complex neurodevelopmental disorder, occurs at heightened rates in children born prematurely. Autism is defined by difficulties with social communication and repetitive and restricted behaviours. The diagnostic deficits in social communication include specific problems with understanding the perspectives of others and the complexities of the social world. Heightened rates of autism in children born preterm suggest that being born early may affect the development of social understanding; however, this has not been confirmed experimentally. Using play-based tasks and eye-tracking methods we aim to describe the profile of social abilities in a cohort of children born preterm.

registration_responses.q17.question:
Short Questionnaire Pack
This will include background information regarding socio-economic status and neonatal history.

Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers – Revised; M-CHAT-R
The M-CHAT-R is a robust screening tool for autism in young children, with high sensitivity and specificity.

Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS)
The ADOS is a widely accepted “gold standard” play-based diagnostic instrument, designed to elicit social interaction and communication behaviours in children including social smiling, responding to name and joint attention. Reports of the psychometric properties of the ADOS reveal high interrater reliability, internal consistency and test-retest reliability 

The Social Orienting Continuum and Response Scale (SOC-RS)
The SOC-RS is an observational coding system of four social orienting behaviours; social referencing, orienting to name, social smiling and joint attention. The SOC-RS employs retrospective coding of social orienting behaviour applied to previously recorded ADOS assessments. This will enable us to capture dimensional ratings of social orienting behaviour using a standardised procedure, to provide richer information that the categorical ratings provided by the ADOS. 

Mullen Scales of Early Learning (MSEL)
The MSEL is an IQ assessment for children aged 0-68 months and provides standardised scores across five domains pertaining to gross motor, visual reception, fine motor, expressive language, and receptive language. The scale is widely used in experimental and developmental psychology in young children. Children in each group will be matched for developmental ability to ensure that any obtained differences in social cognition are not due to developmental ability in children born preterm.

The Early Social Cognitive Battery 
The Early Social Cognition Battery will be used as a direct assessment of early social understanding. The Early Social Cognition Battery is a scaled, play-based assessment that allows for calculation of a total score of early social understanding. The battery includes seven tasks of social cognition, drawn from the existing child development literature and progressing beyond joint attention to assess diverse social cognitive skills. An example of these tasks is the ‘Helping’ assessment where the child watches the adult draw using a pen, and then ‘accidentally’ drop the pen and unsuccessfully reach for it. The child’s response is coded to determine whether they can understand another person’s intentions and unachieved goals. As these seven tasks scale in a known developmental trajectory with published norms, we will test whether children born mid-late preterm show deficits or divergent trajectories in these early social-cognitive skills compared to the term born cohort.

Eye-Tracking
Brief eye-tracking paradigms will be used to evaluate implicit differences in social attention between the two groups. We  will compare children’s attentional preferences when viewing static and dynamic social and non-social stimuli as well as biological motion stimuli. The eye-tracking tasks will capture differences in attention via measures of dwell time and first fixation latency elucidating fundamental attentional processes that may drive deficits or differences in social understanding.

Interviews
Following their assessment day, parents may be contacted to arrange a time convenient to them in the following 6-8 weeks to complete a telephone interview. The interview consists of open ended questions assessing experiences at home. This data will be used to supplement the quantitative data. Interviews will be audio recorded and transcribed by the research team

Further exploratory analysis will also be conducted dependant on data.

q1.value: Favorite possession vs. Best friend on SWB

q2.value: Jingshi Liu, Anirban Mukhopadhyay, Amy N. Dalton

q3.value: This study tests whether reminders of a favorite possession vs. a best friend interacts with people's perception of income inequality to affect their subjective well-being (SWB).

q4.value: Income inequality reduces SWB in the baseline control condition. This effect may be reduced but not mitigated when consumers think about their best friend. This effect is mitigated when consumers think about their favorite possession.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study has a 3 (recall: favorite possession, best friend, baseline control) X 2 (video prime: income inequality in the US, income inequality in another country) between-subjects design.

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to one of the  3 (recall: favorite possession, best friend, baseline control) X 2 (video prime: income inequality in the US, income inequality in another country) condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The study will be posted on Prolific. The study will last about 15 minutes, and participants will received a monetary reward for their participation. All participants must be American residents, above 18 year old, and had not participated in a related study before. Before participants can start the study, they will answer two questions to prove that they are not Robots (one simple human logic question, and one Capcha).

q14.value: The sample size per cell, 100, was pre-determined by G-Power based on a prior study.

q15.value: Data collection will stop automatically when the designated sample size is reached.

question.value:
Recall manipulation: For the favorite possession condition, participants recall and describe their favorite possession. For the best friend condition, participants recall and describe their best friend. For the baseline control condition, participants skip the recall task. Perceived income inequality is measured on a scale. 

Video prime manipulation: Those in the income inequality in the US condition will watch a video about wealth inequality in the US. Those in the income inequality in India condition will watch a video about wealth inequality in India. Both videos can be found on Youtube.

DV = SWB, using the Dienner et al. 1985 scale. 

Potential covariates: materialism, writing task difficulty (for the favorite possession and best friend conditions only), demographic variables: income, gender, age.

All the scale measures that have multiple items will be combined as indexes. Certain items will be reversed coded first, as instructed by the original established scale. Then, the indexes will be computed by taking an average of all the items. We will test the reliability of the scale before creating an index based on the scale items. A Chrombach's alpha of 0.7 is used as a threshold.

We will regress SWB on favorite possession (dummy coded, 1 = favorite possession, 0 = otherwise), best friend (dummy coded, 1 = best friend, 0 = otherwise), video prime (contrast coded, 1 = US inequality, -1 = India inequality), the favorite possession X video prime interaction, and the best friend X video prime interaction. We will also repeat the above analyses with materialism as a covariate.

q20.value: Scale items that need to be reversed coded will be done so based on the instruction of the original scale. Dummy variables will be created for the three possession recall categories, such that 1= specific category, 0 = otherwise.

q21.value: p<.05 is significant. p<.1 but >.05 is marginally significant. Simple effect analyses will be conducted if an interaction is at least marginally significant.

q22.value: Participants who fail an attention check, and who do not comply with the writing task instruction (e.g., writing gibberish, copying and pasting the writing instruction in the text-box). Those who can guess the hypotheses of the study in the funnel debriefing at the end of the study will also be excluded.

q23.value: All the questions, except for the attention check, force responses. So there should be no missing data, except for those who do not complete the study. participants with incomplete responses will be excluded from analyses.

attributes.title: Patient outcome and approppriateness of critical care after ICH

q1.value: Patient outcome and appropriateness of critical care treatment for acute spontaneous Intracerebral Haemorrhage (ICH).

q3.value:
Theoretical Rationale

ICH is a devastating stroke subtype, with high rates of mortality and long-term disability (van Asch et al 2010; Zahuranec et al 2014). The global burden of ICH is set to rise, so data on the impact of early and on-going supportive management for ICH patients in critical care urgently deserve more research. 
Prognosticating after ICH is complex and may be inherently influenced by physicians’ subjective impressions and biases, which may, in turn, influence future decision-making regarding level of care. Prospective data on the accuracy of subjective clinical outcome prediction of survival and long-term ICH outcome after critical care is scarce with most of the available evidence mainly from observational studies (Frick, et al. 2003; Caulfield et al. 2010; Hwang et al. 2016). 
The purpose of the study is to explore the appropriateness of critical care and ICH patient outcome from an “eventual ” and “perceived perspective”. Exploring ICH outcome after critical care and clinicians’ perceptions of outcome aims to provide an in-depth understanding of caring for a group of patients who carry high mortality and morbidity rates. 
Findings will potentially contribute to the rational development of acute care pathways and help shape the organisation of hyperacute stroke critical care services and resources within the UK. Additionally new knowledge and understanding surrounding ICH patient outcome could help inform interprofessional collaborative complex decision making, improve the precision of prognostication, with the overall aim of providing care that is in the best interests of patients and their families.

q4.value: We predict that doctors and nurses will predict poor outcome (mRS 4-6)  more frequently and more accurately than good outcome after spontaneous ICH. Doctors will be more pessimistic than nurses.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Procedure 
The overarching methodology is mixed-methods (MM) research, which provides a means of integrating quantitative and qualitative methods to explore complex phenomena from different perspectives (Parahoo 2014). Combining qualitative and quantitative methods aim to obtain an in-depth understanding of the appropriateness of critical care and ICH patient outcome from both an “eventual” and a “perceived” perspective. 
NOTE: In-order to meet the aims of this study there are three phases, which are briefly described below. The statistical plan that we wish to register refers to phase 3, which will address aim 3.

1: Phase 1 Quantitative Phase – Secondary data analysis (completed)
Phase 1 aimed to determine ICH patients’ functional outcome using the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) at six months following management in critical care compared with that of ICH patients treated in other settings.  Anonymised ICH patient outcome data were analysed from a prospective observational cohort study: Clinical Relevance of Microbleeds in Stroke (CROMIS-2 ICH) study. Ethical approval for this study included patient consent for the use of patient data for future research studies.  
Phase 2: Qualitative Phase (completed)
Using purposive sampling, members of the direct care team (n=21 doctors and nurses) who work in a neurocritical care setting where ICH patients are treated regularly, were interviewed using semi-structured interviews. Phase 2 aimed to explore the perceptions of the appropriateness of critical care for ICH patients and subsequent patient outcome.
Phase 3: Quantitative Phase – Prospective (on-going)
Over a 1 year period (September 2018-September 2019) members of the direct care team within a neurocritical care department in a neuroscience tertiary referral centre in a multi-site acute, central London teaching hospital will be invited by members of an audit team to subjectively predict ICH patient functional outcome at 6 months in the first 48 hours of an eligible ICH patient admission using the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) (Bonita and Beaglehole 1988). Final 6-month outcome from admission to critical care using the mRS will be obtained via home visits and/ or a validated telephone interview from February 2019–March 2020 by designated members of a research team as part of an approved ongoing stroke project (i.e. the NIHR BRC-funded Stroke Investigation in North and Central London (SIGNaL).
Following linkage of perceived 6-month outcome at 48 hours post admission to eventual 6-month outcome, all patient identifiable data collected will be anonymised by the project lead and stored on the approved prospective database (i.e. the NIHR BRC-funded Stroke Investigation in North and Central London (SIGNaL). Following anonymisation, the data will be given to myself, the chief investigator (CI) for subsequent analysis.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Over a 1 year period (September 2018-September 2019) members of the direct care team within a neurocritical care department in a neuroscience tertiary referral centre in a multi-site acute, central London teaching hospital will be invited by members of an audit team to subjectively predict ICH patient functional outcome at 6 months in the first 48 hours of an eligible ICH patient admission using the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) (Bonita and Beaglehole 1988). Final 6-month outcome from admission to critical care using the mRS will be obtained via home visits and/ or a validated telephone interview from February 2019–March 2020 by designated members of a research team as part of an approved ongoing stroke project (i.e. the NIHR BRC-funded Stroke Investigation in North and Central London (SIGNaL).
Following linkage of perceived 6-month outcome at 48 hours post admission to eventual 6-month outcome, all patient identifiable data collected will be anonymised by the project lead and stored on the approved prospective database (i.e. the NIHR BRC-funded Stroke Investigation in North and Central London (SIGNaL). Following anonymisation, the data will be given to myself, the chief investigator (CI) for subsequent analysis.

q13.value:
Sample size and timelines

We anticipate n=200-350 subjective predictions for n=53 ICH patients from a range of members of the direct care team (i.e. doctors and nurses) within the admitting neurocritical in the first 48 hours of an eligible ICH patient admission. It is estimated that each eligible ICH patient will have approximately 4-7 subjective predictions by individual participating members of the direct care team. Final 6-month follow-up from admission to hospital is anticipated to be completed as described above by March 2020.  All patient identifiable data collected will be anonymised. To date, n=315 baseline predictions have been achieved, and the final sample will depend on the number of completed cases.

q14.value:
Power calculation 


We have modelled the power which would be achieved with n=315 observations on the basis of a number of assumed accuracy rates. Previous data has shown that subjective clinical judgement of doctors and nurses correlates more closely with actual 3 month outcome after ICH than prognostic scales (The absolute value of the correlation coefficient for doctors predictions with respect to actual outcome  (Pearson r = 0.75) was higher (r= 0.62, p=0.057) than that of a prognostic scales (r=0.56, p=0.01). Nurse’s predictions of outcome (r= 0.72), also was more accurate than prognostic scales (r= 0.09, p=0.03)(Hwang et al 2016). An earlier study found doctors to have a high predictive accuracy (80%) in determining 6-month outcome in mechanically ventilated neurologic patients of which stroke patients were the largest group. Accuracy for predicting a good outcome (mRS 0-3) was 63% and poor outcome (mRS 4-6) 94%(Caulfield et al 2010). Accuracy for exact agreement between doctors mRS predictions and actual 6-month mRS was only 43% (Caulfield et al 2010).



To determine likely achieved power for the sample, we have modelled a number of  possible outcomes;

Assuming that doctors are correct 80% of the time, and nurses correct 60% of the time, a chi-square with an n of 315 would achieve a power of .97, with an alpha of .05. Assuming that doctors are correct 50% of the time, and nurses correct 30% of the time, a chi-square with an n of 315 would achieve a power of .95, with an alpha of .05. 

Assuming that doctors are correct 75% of the time, and nurses correct 60% of the time, a chi-square with an n of 315 would achieve a power of .81, with an alpha of .05. 
If this n in this sample dropped to 280 (representing higher than anticipated lost to follow on outcomes, this power falls to .76.

In summary, the sample should be capable of detecting accuracy differences of ~15% with a power ~.80. The final achieved sample will depend on completed cases, and a sensitivity analysis will be undertaken and reported on the achieved completed cases sample.

Ratings will be taken from doctors and nurses within 48 hours of an eligible ICH patients’ admission to neurocritical care. Ordinal measures will be taken initially (i.e. 0-6), and then subsequently dichotomized when coding as good (0-3) or poor (4-6). This measure will be provided for each eligible ICH patient by a variable number of (i) doctors and (ii) nurses. 

3: Primary outcome measure: Eventual 6-month outcome following admission to neurocritical care using the modified Rankin Scale (mRS).  6-month eventual outcome will be dichotomized as above, good (mRS 0-3) or poor (mRS 4-6). 
4: Secondary outcome measure: Eventual 6-month outcome following admission to neurocritical care using the modified Rankin Scale (mRS). 6-month outcome will be dichotomized as alive (mRS 0-5) or dead (mRS 6)

Research objectives and planned analysis

Q1: Do doctors and nurses make different early subjective predictions of ICH patient 6-month outcome?
Analysis: 
Q1.1 We will conduct a Mc Nemar’s test (as the data has non-independent observations) of rater (Doctor vs. Nurses) and predicted outcome (good; mRS 0-3 vs. poor; mRS 4-6). 
Q1.2: As above, with predicted outcome being replaced with alive (mRS 0-5) vs. dead (mRS 6)
Q2: 1 How accurate are early subjective predictions of ICH patient outcome of raters with eventual 6-month outcome by rater type?
Analysis: 
We will conduct a McNemar analysis of rater’s  (Doctors correct vs. not correct, Nurses correct vs not correct) with accuracy of predicted outcome (good mRS 0-3 vs. poor mRS 4-6) defining correct vs. incorrect.
Q2.2 Repeat above for dead (mRS 6) vs alive (mRS 0-5) as the defining outcome to explore this nuance also.

registration_responses.q1: Patient outcome and appropriateness of critical care treatment for acute spontaneous Intracerebral Haemorrhage (ICH).
registration_responses.q3:
Theoretical Rationale

ICH is a devastating stroke subtype, with high rates of mortality and long-term disability (van Asch et al 2010; Zahuranec et al 2014). The global burden of ICH is set to rise, so data on the impact of early and on-going supportive management for ICH patients in critical care urgently deserve more research. 
Prognosticating after ICH is complex and may be inherently influenced by physicians’ subjective impressions and biases, which may, in turn, influence future decision-making regarding level of care. Prospective data on the accuracy of subjective clinical outcome prediction of survival and long-term ICH outcome after critical care is scarce with most of the available evidence mainly from observational studies (Frick, et al. 2003; Caulfield et al. 2010; Hwang et al. 2016). 
The purpose of the study is to explore the appropriateness of critical care and ICH patient outcome from an “eventual ” and “perceived perspective”. Exploring ICH outcome after critical care and clinicians’ perceptions of outcome aims to provide an in-depth understanding of caring for a group of patients who carry high mortality and morbidity rates. 
Findings will potentially contribute to the rational development of acute care pathways and help shape the organisation of hyperacute stroke critical care services and resources within the UK. Additionally new knowledge and understanding surrounding ICH patient outcome could help inform interprofessional collaborative complex decision making, improve the precision of prognostication, with the overall aim of providing care that is in the best interests of patients and their families.
registration_responses.q4: We predict that doctors and nurses will predict poor outcome (mRS 4-6)  more frequently and more accurately than good outcome after spontaneous ICH. Doctors will be more pessimistic than nurses.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Procedure 
The overarching methodology is mixed-methods (MM) research, which provides a means of integrating quantitative and qualitative methods to explore complex phenomena from different perspectives (Parahoo 2014). Combining qualitative and quantitative methods aim to obtain an in-depth understanding of the appropriateness of critical care and ICH patient outcome from both an “eventual” and a “perceived” perspective. 
NOTE: In-order to meet the aims of this study there are three phases, which are briefly described below. The statistical plan that we wish to register refers to phase 3, which will address aim 3.

1: Phase 1 Quantitative Phase – Secondary data analysis (completed)
Phase 1 aimed to determine ICH patients’ functional outcome using the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) at six months following management in critical care compared with that of ICH patients treated in other settings.  Anonymised ICH patient outcome data were analysed from a prospective observational cohort study: Clinical Relevance of Microbleeds in Stroke (CROMIS-2 ICH) study. Ethical approval for this study included patient consent for the use of patient data for future research studies.  
Phase 2: Qualitative Phase (completed)
Using purposive sampling, members of the direct care team (n=21 doctors and nurses) who work in a neurocritical care setting where ICH patients are treated regularly, were interviewed using semi-structured interviews. Phase 2 aimed to explore the perceptions of the appropriateness of critical care for ICH patients and subsequent patient outcome.
Phase 3: Quantitative Phase – Prospective (on-going)
Over a 1 year period (September 2018-September 2019) members of the direct care team within a neurocritical care department in a neuroscience tertiary referral centre in a multi-site acute, central London teaching hospital will be invited by members of an audit team to subjectively predict ICH patient functional outcome at 6 months in the first 48 hours of an eligible ICH patient admission using the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) (Bonita and Beaglehole 1988). Final 6-month outcome from admission to critical care using the mRS will be obtained via home visits and/ or a validated telephone interview from February 2019–March 2020 by designated members of a research team as part of an approved ongoing stroke project (i.e. the NIHR BRC-funded Stroke Investigation in North and Central London (SIGNaL).
Following linkage of perceived 6-month outcome at 48 hours post admission to eventual 6-month outcome, all patient identifiable data collected will be anonymised by the project lead and stored on the approved prospective database (i.e. the NIHR BRC-funded Stroke Investigation in North and Central London (SIGNaL). Following anonymisation, the data will be given to myself, the chief investigator (CI) for subsequent analysis.

q2.value: Jingshi Liu, Amy N. Dalton, Anirban Mukhopadhyay

q3.value: This study explores how uploading a photo of one's favorite possession on a social media platform would help mitigate the negative effect of income inequality on people's subjective well-being (SWB).

q4.value:
Income inequality, in general, reduces people's SWB. But this negative effect is mitigated when consumers are reminded of their favorite possessions, by having a chance to upload a photo of such a possession on social media (e.g., Instagram). 

People's SWB may in turn affect their attitude toward the social media platform.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study has a task 2 between-subjects (task order: upload photo first, DVs first) X perceived income inequality (continuous measure) design.

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to one of the two task order conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited on the Turk Prime online platform. Participants will be paid $1.00 for participating the study online. All participants must be U.S. residents, at least 18 years old, and have an above 95% MTurk approval rate. Before they can start the study, they will be ask to pass two questions to make sure they are not a robot (i.e., a Qualtrics Capcha, and a question that requires basic human logic, e.g., up is to down as left is to ___?). Because the study requires participants to take a photo of their favorite possession and upload it on the study, on the recruitment ad, we will ask participants to participate only if 1) they are at home (so that they are likely to have access to their favorite possession) and 2) they are willing to upload a photo in the study.

q14.value: a cell size of 100-130 was determined based on the effect size of a prior study.

q15.value: Data collection will stop once the sample size is reached.

question.value:
Task order: All participants will first report their perception of income inequality in their society. Then, those in the Upload Photo First condition will complete an Instagram Experience Task before responding to the DV measures. In the Instagram Experience Task, they will see an interface that mimics Instagram's #Favoritethings page. They will be ask to take a photo of their favorite possession and upload the photo on this interface. Then, after the Instagram Experience Task they will complete the DV measures (described below). 
Those in the DVs First condition will first complete the DV measures, and then complete the Instagram Experience Task. As such, the DVs First condition is treated as a baseline condition.

Perceived income inequality: participants indicate on a Gini coefficient scale where they think their society falls in terms of income inequality. 
DV1: We use the Satisfaction with Life Scale, which is a 6-item established scale by Diener et al. 1985, to measure subjective wellbeing. 
DV2: A one-item measure for attitudes toward the social media platform (Instagram in this case). 
Demographic variables: gender, age, income, socioeconomic status, Instagram use frequencies. 
Covariate: a 15-item scale measure for materialism, adopted from Richin 1994.

All the scale measures that have multiple items will be combined as indexes. Certain items will be reversed coded first, as instructed by the original established scale. Then, the indexes will be computed by taking an average of all the items. We will test the reliability of the scale before creating an index based on the scale items. A Chrombach's alpha of 0.7 is used as a threshold.

1) We will regress SWB on task order (upload photo first = 1, DVs first = -1), perceived inequality (standardized) and their interaction.
2) We will repeat the analysis in (1) by keeping materialism, income, and socioeconomic status as potential covariates. 
3) We will regress attitudes toward Instagram on SWB. 
4) Should (3) is significant, we will then test whether SWB mediates the indirect effect of task order and perceived inequality on attitude toward Instagram, by using SPSS Process.

q20.value: Scale items that need to be reversed coded will be done so based on the instruction of the original scale.

q21.value: p<.05 is significant. p<.1 but >.05 is marginally significant. Simple effect analyses will be conducted if an interaction is at least marginally significant.

q22.value: Participants who fail an attention check, and who do not comply with the photo upload instructions will be excluded. Those who can guess the hypotheses of the study in the funnel debriefing at the end of the study will also be excluded.

q23.value: All the questions, except for the attention check, force responses. So there should be no missing data, except for those who do not complete the study. participants with incomplete responses will be excluded from analyses.

q24.value: We will test whether Instagram use frequency may further moderate our effects.

Then, those in the Upload Photo First condition will complete an Instagram Experience Task before responding to the DV measures. In the Instagram Experience Task, they will see an interface that mimics Instagram's #Favoritethings page. They will be ask to take a photo of their favorite possession and upload the photo on this interface. Then, after the Instagram Experience Task they will complete the DV measures (described below). 
Those in the DVs First condition will first complete the DV measures, and then complete the Instagram Experience Task. As such, the DVs First condition is treated as a baseline condition.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Perceived income inequality: participants indicate on a Gini coefficient scale where they think their society falls in terms of income inequality. 
DV1: We use the Satisfaction with Life Scale, which is a 6-item established scale by Diener et al. 1985, to measure subjective wellbeing. 
DV2: A one-item measure for attitudes toward the social media platform (Instagram in this case). 
Demographic variables: gender, age, income, socioeconomic status, Instagram use frequencies. 
Covariate: a 15-item scale measure for materialism, adopted from Richin 1994.
registration_responses.q18.question: All the scale measures that have multiple items will be combined as indexes. Certain items will be reversed coded first, as instructed by the original established scale. Then, the indexes will be computed by taking an average of all the items. We will test the reliability of the scale before creating an index based on the scale items. A Chrombach's alpha of 0.7 is used as a threshold.
registration_responses.q19.question:
1) We will regress SWB on task order (upload photo first = 1, DVs first = -1), perceived inequality (standardized) and their interaction.
2) We will repeat the analysis in (1) by keeping materialism, income, and socioeconomic status as potential covariates. 
3) We will regress attitudes toward Instagram on SWB. 
4) Should (3) is significant, we will then test whether SWB mediates the indirect effect of task order and perceived inequality on attitude toward Instagram, by using SPSS Process.

attributes.title: The Psychophysics of ON- Versus OFF- Pattern Recognition and Myopia
attributes.description:
the prevalence of myopia was around 10%, but today nearly 90% of young adults are
afflicted [1]. In the United States and Europe, the prevalence has doubled over the last
half-century with half of young adults now having myopia[1]. The consequence of myopia
extends beyond the inconvenience of using optical correction. Myopia is associated with
increased incidence of diseases such as retinal damage, cataract, and glaucoma [1]. Increased
levels of near-work have commonly been associated with the onset of myopia [2]. It is therefore
important to gain a better understanding of what is happening from a functional and anatomical
standpoint when subjects complete near-work tasks.
There are two different types of text, texts that have positive contrast (white text on a
darker background) and texts that have negative contrast (black text on a lighter background).
Aleman et. al (2018) found that negative contrast texts produced a thinning effect on the choroid
(-16.13土4.54 μm), and positive contrast produced a thickening effect on the choroid(9.96土
6.51μm) [3]. Aleman et. al interpreted these results in the context of ON and OFF pathways in
the visual system [4]. They suggested negative contrast texts stimulate the OFF pathway, while
positive contrast texts stimulate the ON pathway. Choroidal thickening and thinning in both
chicks and marmosets has been observed to be a precursor to a decrease or an increase in axial
growth respectively [5, 6, 7]. The latter leading to the development of myopia. Trolio et. al
documented 20 μm of choroidal thinning in myopia induced marmoset eyes and 12 μm of
thickening in eyes induced with hyperopia [5]. It is hypothesized that the choroid either acts as a
mechanical buffer or a diffusion barrier for the sclera [5].
Qualitatively, Aleman et al’s data showed the thinning effect was more pronounced in
myopic individuals as compared to their emmetropic counterparts [3], but their sample size was
insufficient to draw quantitative conclusions. The plasticity of the human choroid is an important
link to animal models. For example, Read et. al found that among a group of 39 myopic
individuals subfoveal choroidal thickness was 50 μm thinner than nonmyopic age-matched
children [8].
Retinal Ganglion Cells are organized in an ON center OFF surround arrangement or vice
versa [2]. ON cells become depolarized to an increment in light, while OFF depolarize in
response to decrements in light. OFF retinal ganglion cells are twice as numerous and half the
size of ON rental ganglion cells in the fovea. Several studies such as Mazade et. al, Lu et. al, and
Tyler et. al corroborated the different spatial tuning and cortical connectivity of the ON and OFF
pathway [9, 10, 11]. Mazade et al showed maximal cortical responses for small fast stimuli in the
OFF pathway and maximal cortical responses for slow slow global stimuli in the ON pathway
[10]. Zhong-Lin et. al found negative stimuli (or decrements in light) to be 25% more effective
than equal magnitude positive stimuli (or increments in light) across eleven different types of
stimuli [11]. Taken together, these studies support a distinct roles for the ON and OFF pathways
in the visual system.
The goal of our study is threefold. We aim to replicate the changes in choroidal thickness
in response to negative and positive contrast with a larger subject group. We aim to measure the
sensitivity to positive and negative contrast tasks and compare the ratio of contrast sensitivity to
these two contrast types among refractive error/axial length. Finally, we will monitor the changes
in sensitivity to positive and negative contrast as the session proceeds as to understand the
functional implications choroidal thickness changes may have.

q1.value: Does Contrast Polarity Produce Changes in Choroid Thickness Moderated by Refractive Error?

q3.value:
Previous studies by Aleman et al. have shown a correlation between contrast polarity and changes in choroidal thickness with ON- retinal ganglion cell stimulation leading to choroidal thickening and OFF- retinal ganglion cells leading to choroidal thinning. Choroidal thickness have been shown to be an important biomarker for axial length changes, which leads to changes in refractive error and a variety of ocular diseases. 

We hope to replicate these results as well as make statements regarding the correlation between magnitude of choroidal thickness change and refractive error/axial length. We will employ a larger sample size in order to make quantitative statements regarding these correlations.  Unlike the study performed by Aleman et al. we will have subjects running psychophysical tasks instead of passive reading exercises giving us information regarding contrast sensitivity thresholds. These tests will consist of a letter identification task as well as a difference of Gaussian two-alternative forced choice task.

q4.value: Retinal choroidal thickness will increase under ON- retinal ganglion cell conditions and will decrease under OFF- retinal ganglion cell conditions. Additionally, there will be greater thinning form ON- stimuli in myopic individuals as compared to non-myopic individuals.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will use repeated measures with subjects completing two sessions of positive contrast and two sessions of negative contrast tasks.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
A Topcon KR-1W wavefront analyzer was used to determine the patient's refractive
error, and a Haig-Strait Lenstar 900 was used to measure ocular biometry, including choroid
thickness. The wavefront analyzer was only performed on the first session, while biometry was
performed both before and after the completion of psychophysical testing. Testing was
completed on a Vpixx 12-bit monitor with an average luminance of 65cd/m 2 . The subject was
seated 114 cm from the monitor with their head stabilized with a chin-forehead rest.

q13.value:
We will have approximately 50 subjects recruited from the New England College of
Optometry. Subjects were between 18 and 45 (mean age: 25.1土3.83) and were screened to
exclude patients with a past history of ocular disease, ortho-k, and surgery. Seventeen subjects
were male and thirty-eight were female. Spherical equivalent refractive errors ranged from -12 to +6.50 D (mean -3.04土3.26).

q14.value: We used R to conduct a power analysis based on moderate effect size of d=0.33 and a power of 0.75 for choroid thickness measurements. Previous experiment with n=13 found an effect size of R^2=0.5 for choroid thickness relation to refractive error in the ON and OFF contrast polarity.

question.value: The manipulated variable will be contrast polarity (positive or negative) of letters and difference of Gaussian targets.
We will measure choroid thickness using a Haig-Strait Lenstar 900 and refractive error with a Topcon KR-1W wavefront analyzer.

We will use a paired t-test between pre and post choroid thickness in ON and OFF stimuli conditions. Two regressions will be done for the change in choroid thickness related to refractive error for the ON and OFF stimuli.

q21.value: A one-tailed paired t-test (alpha = 0.05) on the change of pre- versus post-test choroid thickness in the ON and OFF conditions.

q23.value: Subjects with incomplete data will be excluded from analysis.
